4.11.text:
My name is Artur Oliveira, and I
am on the Talks at Google team.

8.15.text:
I am very excited to welcome
to Google today the great actor

13.71.text:
He's here to talk
about his new memoir

15.83.text:
"The Bassoon King-- My Life
in Art, Faith, and Idiocy."

19.71.text:
Now, we all know Rainn as
the lovable Dwight Schrute

24.86.text:
But the thing is that
through "The Bassoon King,"

26.91.text:
Rainn really lets us
know who he really is

29.61.text:
and what his career
has been like.

32.08.text:
So with that, I would love
to welcome up Rainn Wilson.

41.24.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: Thank you very
much for coming to Google.

43.61.text:
RAINN WILSON: Hey,
thanks for having me.

53.49.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: We're very
happy that you're here.

55.85.text:
Like I said in the intro,
we all love "The Office,"

58.94.text:
but I think what
I especially loved

61.69.text:
about "The Bassoon
King" is really getting

68.77.text:
And what was really
interesting to me,

73.24.text:
what I wanted to start off
with, is it's easy for us

75.81.text:
to see people who are famous
and think that they just did it.

79.97.text:
The snapped their fingers,
and they got on a TV show,

82.18.text:
they got in a movie,
whatever it is.

83.68.text:
But you talk so much about the

86.85.text:
What made you want
to make yourself so

91.51.text:
RAINN WILSON: Well,
I did research,

93.88.text:
and I had read a lot of
celebrity memoirs when I was

97.59.text:
getting ready to write this,
because I wanted to see what

102.17.text:
And one of the things that
I thought did not work

104.97.text:
was memoirs where I read,
and I didn't know the person

107.68.text:
at the end of the
memoir any more

109.05.text: than I did at the beginning.

110.95.text:
What I responded to, personally,
were the heartfelt stories,

118.79.text:
the vulnerabilities, the
struggles, the ups and downs,

122.24.text:
the roller coaster ride
that the person went on.

124.64.text:
And those are the things
that I could relate

126.59.text: to and kind of learn from.

129.00.text:
And I also found them
to be the funniest,

136.10.text: So I swung for the fences.

139.51.text:
I really was like, I want
this-- I'm going to write one.

143.92.text:
This is who I am and
this is what I'm about.

146.26.text:
And if I walk out here
on Charleston and get

151.45.text:
hit by a bus, and
this is the document

154.87.text:
It's all my failures
and struggles,

156.62.text: and I get hit by the Google bus.

159.56.text:
No one will even look up
from their Wi-Fi computers,

166.00.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: That
would be very tragic.

170.61.text:
There's got to be someone
here who runs the buses.

173.04.text:
They're just kind of panicking
in the back of the room

176.00.text:
RAINN WILSON: But if I
was hit by a Google car,

177.96.text:
it would be going
seven miles an hour,

179.70.text:
so I'd probably
knock the car over.

186.22.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: Thanks
for explaining that.

188.62.text:
Does that also tie in to why
you decided to write it now?

194.24.text:
RAINN WILSON: Well, there
was a window of time,

196.20.text:
and it just seemed like
the right opportunity.

199.01.text:
I finished "The Office,"
and right away I

202.15.text:
shot a pilot for
the show "Backstrom"

204.51.text:
that ran on Fox for a little
while before it was canceled.

209.78.text:
One person groaned,
because no one watched it.

212.84.text:
And then I had this
nice chunk of time,

215.93.text:
and I thought, well,
this is a time to do it.

219.06.text:
Actually, I was here at
Google maybe five years ago,

222.67.text:
where we read from
our SoulPancake book,

229.52.text:
When I wrote the
introduction of that book,

231.31.text:
I saw that there was a
story there that I really

238.25.text:
Yeah, there's the funny stories
of worms coming out of my butt

241.80.text:
in Nicaragua, and being a
starving actor and broke

245.49.text:
and struggling, and trying
to make my way in LA,

248.33.text:
and being a nerd
in high school--

250.77.text:
I know there's a lot
of funny stories.

252.43.text:
But there's also a through line
of my spiritual and artistic

256.45.text:
journey that I
thought made it a book

260.06.text:
and not just a collection
of funny anecdotes.

264.79.text:
It's a very cohesive story
from beginning to end,

266.84.text:
and we can see your
growth as a person

269.69.text:
and as an actor
throughout the book, which

271.74.text:
is why I'm so excited for
everyone to be able to read it.

276.48.text:
So now taking a step
back, I think we're all

282.62.text:
RAINN WILSON: Well, I played
the bassoon for five years

289.76.text: in junior high and high school.

I dug one out about
five or six days ago,

because I had to play it

300.48.text:
I hadn't played a

303.57.text:
But I have a little
section here I'm

307.04.text:
going to read about the
bassoon, and about being

311.30.text: Maybe a few of you can relate.

314.39.text:
A couple, one or
two of you, might

317.77.text:
be able to relate just a
teeny, teeny little bit.

325.09.text:
"I ask you to savor
the following sentence.

327.06.text:
For several years off
and on, I was a member

329.07.text:
of the following clubs at
school-- marching band,

332.16.text:
pep band, orchestra, debate
club, computer club, chess

336.66.text:
club, model United
Nations, and pottery club.

341.63.text:
Note the above list does not
include my aforementioned role

344.85.text:
playing gaming, Baha'i youth
activities, medieval weapons

349.06.text:
sketching, kung fu movie
obsession, or vast Columbia

352.73.text:
Record and Tape Club
cassette collection,

355.36.text:
featuring Journey, Styx,
Asia, and REO Speedwagon.

358.66.text:
And then, if that wasn't enough,
I decided to play the bassoon.

363.57.text:
Boom, universe explodes, then
implodes, then explodes again,

367.49.text:
quickly folding
in on itself, only

369.07.text:
to create infinite other
bassoon-shaped universes.

372.88.text:
Let's dig a little
deeper, shall we?

374.42.text:
Having studied piano as
a kid and then clarinet

376.60.text:
at Kellogg Middle School,
I went to my band teacher

379.40.text:
and told him I wanted to quit
clarinet and play tenor sax.

382.65.text:
Saxophone was way
cooler, you see.

385.23.text:
Guys in the sax section
would crack jokes and wear

392.09.text:
I mean, it wasn't French
horn-- but it certainly

395.84.text:
wasn't the most
masculine of instruments.

398.15.text:
Sure, there was a clarinet-like
instrument in the Cantina scene

401.13.text:
in "Star Wars,"
but let's face it.

403.44.text:
Clarinets are for
girls in braces

405.16.text:
and Woody Allen, who loves
girls in braces, ba-bum, bum.

411.06.text:
My band teacher, John
Law-- real name--

414.49.text: really pulled a fast one on me.

415.78.text:
He said something to
the effect of, well,

417.49.text:
you could play the sax, but
we've got so many saxophones

421.62.text:
Wait a minute-- he paused
for dramatic effect

424.70.text:
and lowered his voice
conspiratorially-- you know

432.73.text: And he was like, the bassoon.

434.67.text:
And I was like,
wow, what's that?

443.62.text:
They should be banned for
being horrible, unnecessary,

449.20.text:
It takes, like, an
hour to assemble one.

451.27.text:
They're enormous,
and are made out

452.69.text:
of Lincoln logs, aluminum
twigs, and paper towel tubes.

456.74.text:
There are these tiny
double wooden reeds

458.41.text:
that you have to soak and
trim and tend to all the time.

461.09.text:
There's a strap
that you actually

462.46.text:
have to sit on when you play
so the whole thing doesn't

465.33.text:
fall onto the floor like
a bundle of garbage.

469.34.text:
And after all that
folderol, it ends up

471.54.text:
sounding like an anemic
donkey with laryngitis.

474.82.text:
I ended up playing the bassoon
for the next five years

478.77.text:
For better or worse,
I spent my adolescence

481.24.text:
tethered to that bastard
woodwind, my siren, my spirit

495.50.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: I'm confident
you just transported everyone

498.56.text:
RAINN WILSON: A

because you have "The

But you also have the

511.64.text:
And I really like

515.11.text:
in the special

516.59.text:
thank your dad for teaching

520.47.text:
Could you talk a little
bit more about your dad

522.43.text:
and the relationship you
had with him growing up?

524.79.text:
Because you have so
many beautiful anecdotes

526.66.text:
you share about your
relationship with him

528.41.text: and the influence he had on you.

530.57.text:
So I talked about the
faith aspect of it,

534.58.text:
which is a little bit risky
too, because people don't really

540.39.text:
Or they don't do
it in a way that's

542.27.text:
funny and a little bit
edgy, like I'm trying to.

546.33.text:
But I grew up a member
of the Baha'i faith,

550.21.text: and my dad was a Baha'i.

551.53.text:
And the way he wove
his spiritual belief

557.87.text:
and his creativity together
were really inspiring.

560.97.text:
So my dad was an
aspiring painter.

566.06.text:
And they were always in our
house, stacked to the ceiling

568.54.text:
and hung on all the walls, and
then he'd swap them out every

572.61.text:
He wasn't very good
at selling them,

574.11.text:
but he was really
good at painting them.

575.82.text:
And he also wrote tons of
science fiction and fantasy

579.41.text: novels while I was growing up.

580.72.text:
So he worked in a sewer
contracting office in Seattle,

586.01.text:
but he would pound away on a
little manual typewriter when

588.43.text:
he wasn't answering
phones, or doing billing,

594.23.text:
He wrote, like, 10 or 12 fantasy
and science fiction novels,

599.12.text:
He always encouraged me
to be creative and extend

605.71.text:
And he was a very devoted
member of the Baha'i faith,

608.57.text:
and was always trying to kind
of deepen his spirituality

614.28.text:
So those are some things
I'm really grateful for.

618.45.text:
On the more negative
side, it was also

622.59.text:
the fact that he was
kind of a failed artist,

624.86.text:
that he wasn't able to achieve
his dream as an artist.

627.50.text:
He was supporting the family
and working day jobs and stuff,

630.63.text:
so he didn't get to
really pursue it.

632.52.text:
That also helped me
to become an actor,

635.44.text:
because I saw what
could happen to someone

638.16.text:
who wanted to be an
artist but wasn't

641.23.text:
able to or willing to commit
completely into that world.

647.84.text:
So when I made that
decision to become an actor,

649.88.text: it was a very serious decision.

651.42.text:
I knew that I was
going to be needing

653.41.text:
to commit 10 years
of my life, at least,

655.83.text:
to intensive training,
and studying with the very

658.32.text:
best people, and
calling myself an actor,

660.88.text:
and really pursuing that dream,
and committing whole hog.

663.98.text:
You can't just do
it on the side.

666.34.text:
So in a way he
also showed me what

670.92.text:
not to do if you
wanted to be an artist.

674.86.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: I love that
journey, and how he helped

678.65.text:
you really make
the decision to go

680.31.text:
to NYU, to really invest in that
part of who you wanted to be.

687.64.text:
I also wanted to ask, as
far as the next generation,

690.34.text:
you talk a lot about how
nerdy you were growing up,

693.44.text:
and you played
Dungeons and Dragons,

694.95.text:
and you read fantasy
and science fiction.

697.03.text:
Is your son following
in your nerdy footsteps?

701.92.text:
He's 11 years old, Walter, and
it's such a different landscape

708.70.text:
When I was a nerd in the
late '70s and early '80s,

711.74.text: it was a very different place.

714.48.text:
There were no nerd television
shows and nerd CEOs,

718.85.text:
and there was no Silicon Valley,
and there was no Bill Gates,

723.30.text:
there was no Beck, there
was no nerd rock stars.

731.65.text:
You were really the
lowest on the totem pole.

737.16.text:
I remember even the
teachers would get in on it.

739.91.text:
There was no concept
of stopping bullying.

745.81.text:
It toughens you up, it gives you
wisdom, and it lets you grow.

750.86.text:
And so teachers growing
up-- I remember,

752.99.text:
some kid with zits in the
corner did something stupid

757.31.text:
and picked his
nose, or something.

760.27.text:
The teacher's like, yeah,
you should kick the crap out

762.63.text: He picked his nose in class.

768.56.text: It was a very different world.

774.61.text:
It just was a matter of course--
you're going to get punched,

777.15.text:
and you're going
to get made fun of.

778.65.text: And that's just how it is.

782.50.text:
My son is in school,
and he does it all.

787.03.text:
So he plays Dungeons and
Dragons with his friends

789.07.text:
on the weekend, and then he's
on the flag football team.

793.76.text:
There doesn't seem to be
any kind of issue with that.

797.70.text:
He really geeks out about
science fiction movies

800.60.text:
and stuff like that, and
music, and at the same time,

805.02.text:
So I think it's a better
time by and large.

809.65.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA:
Better way to grow up.

811.98.text:
You talk a lot-- you
go on, respectfully,

814.80.text:
a little bit of a rant
in the book about how

817.33.text:
being geeky and nerdy
is now considered cool.

820.08.text:
You mentioned the nerdy CEOs,
and TV shows, Silicon Valley,

829.54.text:
What do you think has
caused that cultural shift?

831.88.text:
Is it the importance
of technology

836.53.text:
Is it just purely
money and marketing?

840.39.text:
RAINN WILSON: I think there's
a lot of different factors.

843.36.text:
A couple is we went from a
manufacturing-based economy

848.63.text:
to an information-based economy
over the course of 20 years,

858.24.text:
And I also think that
capitalism is king,

863.04.text:
and the capitalists swiftly
realized, hey, wait a minute.

867.08.text:
These nerds are
making some money.

869.16.text:
And they'll spend that money,
and they'll tell their friends

871.66.text:
to spend that money on movies
and on gadgets and everything.

877.21.text:
So they used to kind of be
shunned, but let's co-opt them.

883.22.text:
So the whole nerd/geek thing
is kind of overly talked about.

888.31.text:
But a lot of it just has
to do with how can we suck

892.65.text: the nerds dry of their cash?

896.82.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: Do
you still play D&D?

899.00.text:
RAINN WILSON: I don't
play D&D anymore.

904.11.text:
I would love to, there's
nothing against it.

910.66.text:
I think the great
thing about hearing

912.65.text:
you talk about that
at Google is the fact

914.50.text:
that for the most part,
almost all of us in this room

917.21.text:
were on a similar boat to
a greater or lesser degree

923.05.text:
And it's great to be able
to identify with someone who

925.51.text:
had that same experience, and
as you said, kind of climbed

928.23.text:
the ladder of nerd-dom
in high school

930.69.text:
until you made it
to theater, and you

932.24.text: were at the top of that ladder.

933.62.text:
RAINN WILSON: I call the
theater geeks the lions

941.69.text:
Theater's at the top
because there are actually

944.02.text:
cute girls in the theater, who
if you make them laugh enough,

948.91.text:
they will potentially
make out with you.

955.27.text:
I transferred high schools
from Seattle to Chicago

957.64.text:
and they had a good
theater department there,

959.60.text:
and I did this-- I have a
chapter called "How Elvis

966.17.text:
Because they had an exercise
called private in public.

970.99.text:
It's a very common theater
exercise where you just

974.98.text:
act out as if you're
in your bedroom,

978.70.text:
So I put on Elvis
Costello's "Mystery Dance"

983.87.text:
And I just started
thrashing around, pretending

986.45.text:
I was in my bedroom just
goofing off to the song,

988.61.text: and lip syncing it and stuff.

990.04.text: And it brought the house down.

992.83.text:
I had recently moved
into that school.

994.69.text:
And then all the
girls, at the end,

996.84.text:
they were like, oh,
you're so funny.

999.22.text: Will you sit at our lunch table?

1001.76.text:
You should try out
for the next play!

1003.34.text:
And I was just like, huh,
girls have talked to me.

1010.81.text:
So I left the others-- model
United Nations, chess team,

1021.52.text:
We were drama geeks at
University of Washington

1024.34.text:
together and ended
up dating later on,

1027.41.text:
and now have been
together for 25 years.

1037.06.text:
ARTUR OLIVEIRA: You've
talked about the art part,

1039.46.text: and I want to get to the faith.

1040.75.text:
But I can't not ask you about
the idiocy of the title.

1044.59.text:
Why did you choose to
include that in the title,

1047.73.text: and what do you mean by that?

1049.92.text:
RAINN WILSON: Well,
part of the idiocy

1051.50.text:
is just the stupid
things that I've done

1054.52.text:
and the things that
I've experienced.

1057.45.text:
I wanted to really make
myself vulnerable in the book.

1062.20.text:
I think that's the only
way to do a book like this.

1065.15.text:
So there's a lot of things I
end up looking pretty stupid.

1069.55.text:
I've made a lot of mistakes
on this road, of all kinds.

1078.97.text:
You know, it's not
really an idiocy thing,

1081.97.text:
but one of the
chapters is called

1085.09.text:
"How I Bombed on
Broadway." and I

1087.55.text:
think it's a very telling
story at the center.

1090.50.text:
Because I was out of acting
school for a few years,

1094.83.text:
and I was working as an
actor, and I got cast

1098.41.text:
It was at the Roundabout
Theatre Company on Broadway.

1101.78.text:
And it was kind of an English
restoration, stylized comedy

1112.13.text:
I got really stuck early on
in the rehearsal process.

1116.79.text:
I always have had this
issue, this character defect,

1120.37.text:
of just wanting approval and
wanting people to like me.

1122.81.text:
So I got cast and I had
these thoughts like, oh, I

1128.27.text:
I could get a great
"New York Times" review.

1130.57.text: I could get a great agent.

1132.78.text:
I could get
discovered from this.

1134.94.text:
I had all these
visions of sugar plums.

1137.15.text:
And I got really
stuck in the role.

1141.28.text: I couldn't get out of it.

1143.56.text:
I was very robotic
and stiff, and it just

1149.38.text:
I'd call my wife at
3:00 in the morning

1152.10.text: and sob to her about it.

1154.28.text:
And I just couldn't
get out of it,

1157.16.text: and it was eating me up inside.

1159.32.text:
And then when I finished
that, I remember going out

1162.67.text:
on 44th Street near
Broadway in New York,

1165.52.text: and I was like, you know what?

1169.60.text:
I'm not ever going
to do that again.

1172.29.text:
Whatever just happened,
I'm not going to do it.

1175.66.text:
I can't be some
external idea of what

1179.27.text:
it is to be a New York actor,
wanting approval, wanting

1182.56.text:
to be liked, thinking
I needed to be

1188.36.text:
All of that stuff, I
just really jettisoned.

1191.11.text:
I was like, I'm a quirky
guy, I'm an oddball,

1196.33.text:
I need to play roles
that are like that.

1198.66.text:
I need to use who I am
in those kind of roles.

1202.46.text:
And that's when
I started slowly,

1205.30.text:
slowly having more
and more success.

1208.79.text:
So when I look back on it,
it was a horrible experience.

1212.23.text:
Bombing on Broadway
and getting bad reviews

1214.40.text:
and sucking in front
of 1,000 people

1216.23.text:
every night for three months or
four months, it really sucks.

1221.24.text:
And yet had I not
gone through that,

1224.18.text:
I never would have
played Dwight.

1226.05.text:
I wouldn't have had the tools,
I wouldn't have had the skill

1229.13.text:
set and the belief
in myself to play

1232.11.text:
such an odd, quirky
character that draws

1234.43.text: on a lot of my own odd quirks.

1237.19.text:
So I think that's
how life works.

1239.84.text:
You can look at it as
a psychological lesson,

1242.10.text:
a sociological lesson, a
spiritual lesson, if you like.

1244.75.text:
But those fires and
those tests, often time

1248.30.text:
when you get the luxury of
looking back on your life

1250.64.text:
and having written a
memoir, which is something

1253.08.text:
I recommend for everyone,
whether you're on TV or not,

1257.18.text:
Because it's a really
interesting perspective

1259.16.text:
to look back on your life, and
you see how it was those tests

1264.44.text: that make us who we are.

1267.35.text:
